com.jchugh.hyperloglog

Class Cardinality

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.jchugh.hyperloglog.Cardinality

  • public class Cardinality
extends java.lang.Object
    Based on the HyperLogLog algorithm. Computes cardinality with error less than 1.04/sqrt(2 ^ logRegisterCount) for cardinality approaching 10^9. At 10^9, the error percentage varies around 1-1.8% The register size is fixed at 8 bits for ease and simplicity of implementation. The hashing algorithm used is MurmurHash3 from Guava library The class is ThreadSafe Except for the getCardinalityAsync() method.
    Author:
    jchugh

    • Constructor Detail

      • Cardinality

        public Cardinality(int logRegisterCount)
        This class and all it's methods except getCardinalityAsync() are ThreadSafe
        Parameters:
        logRegisterCount - the log2 of Number of registers you wish to use, eg 16 registers = 4 logRegisterCount (log2(16) = 4). This value has to be between 4 and 16 (min and max inclusive).
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if logRegisterCount is given a value outside of the specified range.

        public void offer(byte[] input)
        Submit a byte[] input. You can use offer(String, Charset) for Strings.
        Parameters:
        input - the byte[] input

      • getCardinalitySync

        public long getCardinalitySync()
        Get the cardinality of the inputs received so far. While the cardinality is calculated, no more values can be added. that snapshot. Useful when cardinality is needed less often, but slows down the system if getCardinality() is called a lot. Check getCardinalityAsync()
        Returns:
        cardinality

      • getCardinalityAsync

        public long getCardinalityAsync()
        Use With Caution this method is NotThreadSafe Get the cardinality of the inputs received so far. Async. While the cardinality is calculated, you can still add data to the registers, this may result in slightly skewed cardinality for the instance it was called. Warning: Another thread can call reset() while this executes.
        Returns:
        cardinality of the items seen so far

      • reset

        public void reset()
        Reset all the registers to 0. Creates a new list of registers, leaving previous one to be gc'd.
